title: Stephen Hendry backs Judd Trump to triumph in rivalry with Ronnie O’Sullivan
text:
Judd Trump got the better of Ronnie O’Sullivan in two big finals last season (Picture: Getty Images)

Stephen Hendry has backed Judd Trump to emerge victorious from the much-anticipated rivalry with Ronnie O’Sullivan that will unfold over the coming months and years.

Trump, the world champion and world number one, is the new force at the top of the game, while O’Sullivan remains the bookies favourite to win any tournament he enters and sits at number two in the world, despite skipping a number of ranking events.

The pair met in three tremendous battles last season, with Trump winning the finals of the Northern Ireland Open and the Masters, while O’Sullivan gained a measure of revenge in the Players Championship semi-finals with a 10-9 victory.

The world’s top two players are yet to face each other this season, and debate is raging among snooker fans over who would come out on top when they inevitably are drawn together.

Seven-time world champion Hendry has voiced his opinion, believing the Rocket remains the better player, but he sees the world champion as the more likely winner.

‘Ronnie is still the more complete player and his cue ball control superior but for some reason I expect Judd to win more of their matches together,’ Hendry tweeted.

Ronnie is still the more complete player and his cue ball control superior but for some reason I expect judd to win more of their matches together https://t.co/dYnxS03eBm — stephen hendry (@SHendry775) October 16, 2019

Trump and O’Sullivan are on course to meet for the first time this season at the English Open, but there is work to be done before a potential blockbuster semi-final clash.

The world champion and the UK champ are in the same half of the draw in Crawley and can meet in the last four, but they have three more rounds to slog through before that stage.

Fans will be desperate to see the mouth-watering contest, which would take place this Saturday, if the Juddernaut and the Rocket can make it from the last 32 to the final four successfully.

The third and fourth rounds are played on Thursday, with neither man expected to have much trouble in the last 32 where O’Sullivan plays Hossein Vafaei and Trump meets Lee Walker.

Stephen Hendry is never shy to give an opinion (Picture: Getty Images)

Both men have a title to their names already this season, with Trump winning the International Championship and O’Sullivan retaining his Shanghai Masters title.

The Rocket’s win in China made it 27 straight seasons with a title to his name and he has challenged his rivals to try and match his incredible longevity in the game.

‘I don’t have anything to prove to anyone,’ O’Sullivan said after claiming the Shanghai crown. ‘I just think for me, and the snooker fans, for me top keep playing as long as I can, I think the fans enjoy seeing me play but they don’t expect me to have to prove myself anymore.

‘I have a different model, it’s just about enjoying it and having fun.

‘For the other guys like Shaun [Murphy], Neil [Robertson] and Judd [Trump], they’ve still got to try and chase them records that I’ve got.

‘If they want to try and go down as one of the greats, it’s okay doing it in a season or over two or three years, but you’ve got to try and do it over a decade or two decades and I’ve done that.’
